{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3565283,"name":"Austin Yu","username":"Justmore5mins","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T11:17:16.427Z","cooked":"

how do I reveal my differential drive chassis position?
here’s my code

    SmartDashboard.putData("RobotPos", builder -> {
        super.initSendable(builder);
        builder.setSmartDashboardType("DifferentialDrive");
        builder.addDoubleProperty("Robot Angle",() -> gyro.getRotation2d().getDegrees(), null);
        builder.addDoubleProperty("Left Motor Speed",() -> LeftMotor.get(), null);
        builder.addDoubleProperty("Right Motor Speed", () -> RightMotor.get(), null);    
    });

we use the AHRS gyro and SparkMax NEO motor, and here’s the output of ElasticDashboard and simulation terminal

image772×504 21.9 KB

NT: ERROR: reached maximum number of publishers to ‘/SmartDashboard/RobotPos/.controllable’, not publishing (LocalStorageImpl.cpp:329)
NT: ERROR: reached maximum number of publishers to ‘/SmartDashboard/RobotPos/.type’, not publishing (LocalStorageImpl.cpp:329)

I can’t see the outer context of where that code is, but I suspect you’re calling it from within periodic, which is not correct.

You want to do exactly one or the other of these things, not both:

  1. Use the Sendable framework, call InitSendable once.
  2. Call putData periodically.
  3. But not both 1 & 2

From the code and error message, it looks like you’re probably calling initSendable every 20ms, which is creating too many publishers and the error you’re seeing.

You don’t want to addDoubleProperty in periodic either.

You either want to addDoubleProperty once in an initializer or you want to putNumber [or putData] every periodic. Right now, you’re mixing the Sendable framework and the SmartDashboard putData framework together, giving you those errors.

We don’t have a differential drive sample that I can cite for you, but that might get you to a solution, or I can take a half hour later today and whip up some sample code for you. I think you’re going to land it yourself here, though.

This is the Sendable framework docs (here is a second link for writing your own). When you use that framework, you call that once (ever) and the data is published automatically.

There is also the SmartDashboard direct publishing framework docs. When you use this, you need to manage calling putBoolean, putNumber, etc. in periodic (or whenever you want the data to be updated).

They will both accomplish the end goal, but you shouldn’t call the Sendable framework methods over and over (as each one will create a new periodic publisher, when you only need one).

Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T13:35:16.777Z","cooked":"

The design of the SmartDashboard API is a little counterintuitive—putData is different than all the other put functions. Most of the put functions are entirely safe to be called periodically, but putData stores the passed object (because it needs to call back into it). If you pass the same object each time, it can be called periodically, but issues rapidly arise if you pass different objects, which is what is happening here (the lambda creates a new object each time).

I’m currently working on a new Telemetry API (to replace the SmartDashboard and Sendable APIs) that will remove this design wart, as it doesn’t use a callback-based model and thus won’t need to store objects.
